facts.text: These are appeals by special leave against the decision of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras, dated January 29, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: These are appeals by special leave against the decision of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, madras, dated January 29, 1953, passed in three appeals I.T.A. Nos. 3489, 3490 and 3491 of 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant carries on business in arrack. He also runs a lorry. For the assessment year 1945-46, the Income-tax Officer found that the income chargeable to tax was Rs. 54,600.

anchor.surface_text: and for the assessment year 1947-48, he held that it was Rs. 54,500. These amounts appear in the account books of a firm of which the appellant is a partner as credits from him.

facts.text: The amounts Rs. 54,600, Rs. 27,500, Rs. 54,500 appear in the account books of a firm as credits from the appellant, of which he is a partner.

anchor.surface_text: These amounts appear in the account books of a firm of which the appellant is a partner as credits from him. The appellant was asked to give an explanation as to how he came to possess these amounts.

facts.text: Appellant's father made profits of about Rs. 80,000 in arrack business conducted by him, had this amount when he died in 1936.

facts.text: Prior to his death, appellant's father entrusted Rs. 80,000 to the assessee's aunt.

anchor.surface_text: that prior to his death he entrusted this amount to the assessees aunt, that she died in 1944, and before here death, she handed this amount over to the appellant.

facts.text: Balance of about Rs. 42,000 represented profits earned in a partnership concern carrying on arrack business during 1938-39 to 1944-45.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the balance of about Rs. 42,000, the explanation of the appellant was that they represented the profits earned in a partnership companycern which carried on business in arrack during the years 1938-39 to 1944-45.

facts.text: Partners of that firm were Ediga Thayappa and M. Govindaswamy Mudaliar.

anchor.surface_text: The partners of that firm were two persons, viz., Ediga Thayappa and M. Govindaswamy mudaliar. the case of the appellant is that Ediga Thayappa was only a benamidar for him,

facts.text: Ediga Thayappa was a benamidar for the appellant in the partnership.

anchor.surface_text: the case of the appellant is that Ediga Thayappa was only a benamidar for him, and that the profits earned by the business during these years were the profits in which he had a share and that came to Rs. 42,000.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected both explanations and held the amounts as concealed income.

anchor.surface_text: This story was rejected by the Income-tax officer. Both the explanations of the appellant having been rejected, the Income-tax officer held that the amounts in question represented companycealed income and imposed tax thereon.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who agreed with ITO.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who again, on an investigation of the facts, agreed with the companyclusions of the Income- tax officer.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal confirmed AAC decision by judgment dated January 29, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: All the points urged before us were taken in the reference under section 66 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act. It would therefore follow that these grounds are number open to the appellant.

Whether a receipt is to be treated as income or number, must depend very largely on the facts and circumstances of each case. In the present case the receipts are shown in the account books of a firm of which the appellant and Govindaswamy Mudaliar were partners. When he was called upon to give explanation he put forward two explanations, one being a gift of Rs. 80,000 and the other being receipt of Rs. 42,000 from business of which he claimed to be the real owner. When both these explanations were rejected, as they have been it was clearly upon to the Income-tax Officer to hold that the income must be companycealed income. There is ample authority for the position that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amount of cash received during the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipt are of an assessable nature.

concepts.interpretation: Assessee fails to prove source and nature of cash credits; Income-tax Officer entitled to infer they are undisclosed income of assessable nature

issues.text: Whether, upon the assessee failing to establish his explanations for the source of cash credits of Rs. 80,000 and Rs. 42,000, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to treat them as concealed income from undisclosed sources without the Department adducing evidence of the source

anchor.surface_text: Now the contention of the appellant is that assuming that he had failed to establish the case put forward by him, it does number follow as a matter of law that the amounts in question were income received or accrued during the previous year, that it was the duty of the Department to adduce evidence to show from what source the income was derived and why it should be treated as companycealed income. In the absence of such evidence, it is argued, the finding is erroneous. We are unable to agree.

issues.text: Whether the appellant can raise the same grounds in an appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution against the Tribunal's decision after the High Court dismissed the reference application under section 66(2) of the Income-tax Act without appeal

anchor.surface_text: We must mention that against the order of the Tribunal the appellant applied for reference to the High Court under section 66 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, and the learned Judges of the High Court dismissed that application. No appeal has been preferred against that a all. The present appeal is against the decision of the Tribunal itself. It is numberdoubt true that this companyrt has decided in Dhakeswari Cotto Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal, that an appeal under article 136 of the Constitution of India to this companyrt again a decision of the Appellate tribunal under the Indian Income-tax Act. But seeing that in this case the appellant had moved the High Court an a decision has been pronounced adverse to him and this has become final, obviously it would number be upon to his to question the companyrectness of the decision of the Tribunal on grounds which might have been take in an appeal against the judgment of the High Court. All the points urged before us were taken in the reference under section 66 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

holdings.text: Where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amount of cash received during the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipts are of an assessable nature.

anchor.surface_text: There is ample authority for the position that where an assessee fails to prove satisfactorily the source and nature of certain amount of cash received during the accounting year, the Income-tax Officer is entitled to draw the inference that the receipt are of an assessable nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cash credits appeared in firm account books during relevant years; assessee offered two explanations both rejected on evidence; failure to prove source and nature permits ITO to infer assessable income from undisclosed sources; supported by ample precedent.

holdings.text: The conclusion to which the Appellate Tribunal came appears to us to be amply warranted by the facts of the case. There is no ground for interfering with that finding, and these appeals are accordingly dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant sought reference to High Court under s.66(2) which was dismissed; no appeal against that final adverse decision; thus cannot question Tribunal decision on same grounds via direct Art.136 appeal, distinguishing cases without prior High Court reference.
